~ Stephen 
Hawking 
Pluto was reclassified as a dwarf planet in 2006 losing 
its status as a planet. This move caused much 
controversy and debate. Contradictory believes of 
considering Pluto a full-fledged planet or not is an 
interesting discussion that made one thing certain: The 
object is shrouded in mystery, and we don't have a 
complete picture of what it would be like to live there. 
We've never been to anywhere like Pluto.  
Unmanned exploratory missions can collect data but 
they cannot detect weird microscopic life-forms that are 
not in our database yet. At least not yet. They are not 
programmed to recognize what might be lurking below 
the surface of Charon, or beneath the icy murky seas of 
Pluto. Astronaut missions are expensive and riskier than

IAC-16-A5,IP,10,x35345                  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Page 2 of 6 
unmanned missions but they are absolutely vital for the 
success of our exploration program.  
So in this paper, the propaganda is to explore the 
possibilities of a manned mission to Pluto and study 
about the major celestial figures in Pluto’s orbit and 
Kuiper Belt. 
 
2. Pluto  
Pluto is the largest known dwarf planet in the solar 
system and was once considered the ninth and most 
distant planet from the sun. Beyond the gas giant 
Neptune lies an entire region of space filled with icy 
bodies known as the Kuiper Belt, of which Pluto is the 
largest 
known 
member 
of. 
In 
2006, 
Pluto 
was reclassified as a dwarf planet, a change widely 
considered as a demotion. This question of Pluto's 
celestial status attracted a lot of controversies and stirred 
a debate in the scientific community, and among the 
general public as well.  
Launched on January 19, 2006, NASA's New Horizons 
spacecraft flashed past Pluto on July 14, 2015. From 
Pluto’s unusual heart-shaped region to its extended 
atmosphere and intriguing moons, New Horizons has 
revealed a degree of diversity and complexity in the 
Pluto system that few expected in the frigid outer 
reaches of the solar system. 
 
3.  Composition & Structure 
3.1 Atmospheric Composition - Nitrogen, methane. 
Observations by New Horizons reveals that 
atmosphere of Pluto extends as far as sixteen 
hundred kilometers (1,000 miles) above the 
surface of the dwarf planet. 
 
3.2 Magnetic Field - Although unknown about the 
existence of Pluto’s magnetic field, the slow 
rotation and small size of the dwarf planet 
suggest it has little to no such field. 
 
3.3 Chemical Composition - Estimating a mixture 
of 30 percent water ice and 70 percent rock is 
quite probable. 
 
3.4 Internal Structure - Pluto probably has a rocky 
core enclosed within a mantle of water ice 
along with more exotic ices such as carbon 
monoxide, methane and nitrogen ice coating 
the entire surface. 
 
4. Orbit and Rotation 
Pluto's rotation is retrograde compared to the other 
worlds of our solar systems. It spins from east to 
west.

kilometers (3,670,050,000 miles) which is 
39.482 times the distance of Earth.

5. Sending Man to Pluto 
The next logical step for further expansion of our 
technically bounded horizons would be of a robotic 
Pluto lander followed by manned mission to Pluto. New 
Horizons is currently the fastest spacecraft that has ever 
left Earth. It crossed Jupiter’s orbit the very next year of 
its launch and had travelled nearly a million miles in a 
day. Still it took about 9.5 years for the spacecraft to 
reach Pluto and its moons. Organizing a manned 
mission will require additional 10 years for their return 
back. Food, air, water, fuel, exercise and life in zero 
gravity for 20 years would make any team going 
incapable of living back on the Earth for a longer period 
of time after their return from the mission. In order to 
overcome that, time duration of the mission needs to be 
compensated.

Potsdam, 20 June 2024 
 
Subject: Reference for Shashank Pathak 
 
 
Dear Sir or Madam, 
I take great pleasure in recording my impressions about Mr. Shashank Pathak. In my capacity 
as the Senior Lecturer of Geodesy Curriculum at the Technical University Berlin and a Senior 
Scientist at Helmholtz Centre Potsdam - German Research Centre for Geosciences GFZ, my 
acquaintance with him has spread over his last 4 years of education, and it has given me an 
opportunity to observe him closely and judge his capabilities. I had a fair amount of interaction 
with him as he took my course “Introduction to Satellite Geodesy” and showed very curious 
attitude to new ideas and he could answer many questions during the lectures. 
His research work was found to be quite interesting and his methods of approaching problems 
is an example of out-of-the-box thinking as he presented a Master’s thesis titled "Prediction 
of Earth Orientation Parameters using Machine Learning" under my mentorship. In his thesis, 
he introduced innovative machine learning models, particularly focusing on neural networks, 
for the prediction of time series data of Earth Orientation Parameters (EOPs). Utilizing seven 
different types of prediction algorithms, including Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks 
and Seasonal Autoregressive Integrated Moving Average (SARIMA) models, he aimed to 
identify patterns and to improve prediction accuracy. Shashank's impeccable understanding 
of these machine learning techniques and their application to geodetic data enabled him to 
implement many new approaches that aligned with the stringent prediction guidelines of the 
European Space Agency (ESA). 
Shashank has successfully completed his Masters in Space Engineering with his major in 
Satellite Geodesy from Technical University Berlin. As a teacher with many years of 
experience, I am confident that Shashank will be a great addition to the engineering/research 
community with his enthusiastic and refreshing mind. I am positive that his work will carve 
the way for innovative projects in the professional community. His intellectual capacity along 
with his scientific curiosity and enthusiasm would be a positive marker toward his success. 
Please accept my sincere recommendation for Shashank for higher studies/research or for 
project work in your industry. I am positive that he will be an asset to your institution. Please 
don’t hesitate contacting me for further information. 
 
Yours faithfully, 
 
   Robert Heinkelmann

considering Pluto a full-fledged planet or not is an
interesting discussion that made one thing certain: The
object is shrouded in mystery, and we don't have a
complete picture of what it would be like to live there.
We've never been to anywhere like Pluto.
Robotic missions are much cheaper and may provide
more scientific information, but they don't catch the
public imagination in the same way, and they don't
spread the human race into space, which I'm arguing
should be our long-term strategy. “If the human race is
to continue for another million years, we will have to
boldly go where no one has gone before." ~ Stephen
Hawking
Unmanned exploratory missions can collect data but
they cannot detect weird microscopic life-forms that are
not in our database yet. At least not yet. They are not
programmed to recognize what might be lurking below
the surface of Charon, or beneath the icy murky seas of
Pluto. Astronaut missions are expensive and riskier than
Pluto was reclassified as a dwarf planet in 2006 losing
its status as a planet. This move caused much
unmanned missions but they are absolutely vital for the
success of our exploration program.
So in this paper, the propaganda is to explore the
possibilities of a manned mission to Pluto and study
about the major celestial figures in Pluto’s orbit and
Kuiper Belt.

What Next?
Beyond the gas giant
Neptune lies an entire region of space filled with icy

Launched on January 19, 2006, NASA's New Horizons
spacecraft flashed past Pluto on July 14, 2015. From
Pluto’s unusual heart-shaped region to its extended
atmosphere and intriguing moons, New Horizons has
revealed a degree of diversity and complexity in the
Pluto system that few expected in the frigid outer
reaches of the solar system.
The most advanced propulsion systems in our
technological grasp today requires 10 to 15 years for
delivering 1.6-kilogram (3.5 lbs.) spacecraft in Pluto’s
orbit. The International Space Station (ISS) has been
continuously orbiting around the Earth, manned, since
Oct. 31, 2000. There is, of course, a wide difference
between the ISS and a manned Pluto spacecraft
including the lack of significant propulsion. The ISS has
been resupplied and occupied by crews rotating from
Earth several times per annum for the past 14 years.
Whereas, astronauts traveling to Pluto would be utterly
isolated with self-contained life supporting systems. The
longest period of a human spending time in space has
been recorded of 437 days and no self-contained, closed
biosphere has the capacity of holding human life for
more than two years.
The only known spacecraft propulsion technology
that is capable of delivering a multihundred-ton manned
spacecraft to Pluto within a year has been laying around
since 1950s and is titled Project Orion. The concept of
this technology is to propel the spacecraft by exploding
thousands of small nuclear bombs fixated behind it.
Each detonation drives a "pusher plate" of the spacecraft
by an enormous set of shock absorbers. The exhaust
velocities created are 10s-100s of kilometres per second
with millions of tons of thrust. The project essentially
worked out in 1960s was revisited by NASA in 2000
4.1 Average distance from the sun - 5,906,380,000
kilometers (3,670,050,000 miles) which is
39.482 times the distance of Earth.
under the name of External Pulsed Plasma Propulsion.
The Physicist from 1960s developed an advanced
interplanetary configuration which was capable of
delivering a 10,000-ton spacecraft to Saturn and return
back in three years. Such a spacecraft could not be
launched directly from the Earth's surface due to its
nuclear fallout. Instead, it could be constructed in the
orbit of Earth, with the help of ISS and depart for Pluto
from there. In a couple of years, the nuclear powered
spacecraft would decelerate into orbit around Pluto
while turning off its engines. Human carrying ship
descending to Pluto's surface would use more
conventional chemical rockets. Gravitational force on
Pluto’s Surface is about 1/12 of Earth's (half of the
moon’s as well). Landing on the surface from a low
orbit at an altitude of 100 kilometres (62 miles) will
require half the Delta-V of a landing on the moon from
the same height (i.e. Eight hundred meters per second
versus seventeen hundred meter per second).
Psychological and biological factors are vital concern.
The crew can be induced to hibernation, an alternative
to the problems of survival making them easier to
resolve. Hibernation is a kind of torpor, or reduced
metabolism which can be induced by hypothermia.
Unlike in cryogenics, the body will not actually freeze.
A 10 degree drop in the temperature of body can
reduces metabolic rate by 50 to 70 percent. Dormant
astronauts would be immobilized in their special
hibernation capsules. They will not require pressurized
living space or artificially generated gravity.
6. Touching Down on Pluto
Landing on Pluto would present some unique
challenges especially if the spacecraft is manned.
Pluto’s surface has a thin atmosphere of methane,
nitrogen and carbon monoxide. The surface pressure of
Pluto varies from 6.5 to 24 microbars about as thick as
Earth's atmosphere 80 kilometres (50 miles) up. This is
not enough to provide any useful aero-braking
capability (like a parachute) but enough to require some
kind of heat shield.
An equipment to be considered for that to overcome is
SpaceX's Dragon V2 capsule. It is probably a step in the
right direction as it combines heat shield with
propulsive landing rockets. The Dragon V2 can store
enough fuel for 300 meter per second Delta-V, so extra
fuel tanks are needed in order to take off, land and
rendezvous with the orbiting mother ship. The
technology available seems feasible for the project.
There might be other hazards to be considered. Surface
of the Moon is made mostly of silicate rock. Whereas,
Pluto is covered with ice. Not just water ice, but frozen
nitrogen, carbon monoxide and methane. On contact
with extremely hot rocket exhaust at thousands of
degrees, there's a real danger of the vaporization of the
landing site. Some previous equipment’s are needed to
be transported in order to create a stable landing surface
for the first Pluto explorers.
Fig 1-
Scientists are hoping to induce an unconscious
state in astronauts so that they can be stored in cold
capsules for long space flights.
Radiation is a major concern in deep-space travel.
Heavy shielding against radiation could be provided
only to the crew’s sleep capsules and the large living
areas of the ship are saved from this technological
implement, saving a lot of weight and fuel.
8. Kuiper Belt
Beyond the gas giant Neptune lies the third zone of
solar system, a region of space filled with icy bodies.
This region is known as the Kuiper Belt, this chilly
expanse in space holds trillions of mysterious objects
that are remnants of the early solar system.
The Kuiper Belt is an elliptical plane in the later solar
system spanning from thirty to fifty times Earth's
distance from the sun, or 4.5 to 7.4 billion kilometres
(2.5 to 4.5 billion miles). The belt appears similar to the
asteroid belt found between
Mars
and Jupiter, although
objects in the Kuiper Belt tend more towards icy in
nature rather than rocky.
The time duration for the entire journey can be
exhausting. And knowing no bounds to human minds,
the atmosphere inside the spacecraft can get homicidal.
Pluto was the first truly recognized Kuiper Belt Object,
although scientists didn't recognize it as such at that
time. The existence of the belt could not be realized
until scientists discovered a slowly moving, small world
in the outer region of our solar system in 1992 (Jane
Luu and David Jewitt found the KBO, 1992QB1.).
Other discoveries soon followed, and astronomers
quickly realized that the region beyond Neptune was
filled with icy rocks and tiny worlds.
Sedna, about three-fourth of the size of Pluto, was
discovered in 2004. It is so far away from the sun that it
takes about 10,500 years to make one single orbit.
Sedna is about 1,770 kilometers (1,100 miles) wide and
revolves around the sun on an eccentric orbit that ranges
between 12.9 billion kilometers (8 billion miles) and
135 billion kilometers (84 billion miles).
On July 2005, astronomers announced the discovery of
a large object in the Kuiper Belt thought to be even
larger than Pluto, though subsequent observations
denied the previous observations and it was found
slightly smaller. Dubbed as Eris, it orbits the sun
approximately once in every 580 years, traveling almost
a hundred times farther from the sun than Earth. Eris’s
discovery disputed the problem of terming Pluto a full-
scale planet between the astronomers, and in 2006, Eris,
Pluto, and the largest asteroid Ceres were classified as
dwarf planets. Two more dwarf planets were discovered
in the Kuiper Belt in 2008 known as
Haumea and Makemake.
9. Moons of Pluto
Pluto has five moons orbiting around: Charon, Nix, Styx,
Kerberos and Hydra, where Charon being the closest
and Hydra being the most distant to Pluto.
Unlike Pluto’s surface, Charon's surface appears to be
dominated by less volatile water ice. In 2007,
observations made by the Gemini Observatory of
patches of water crystals and ammonia hydrates on the
surface of Charon suggested the presence of
active cryogeysers and cryovolcanoes.
discovered along with Hydra (Pluto's outermost
satellite) in June 2005.
Nix follows a circular orbit in the same plane
as Charon. Its orbital period of 24.9 days. It is in a
3:2 orbital resonances with Hydra, and a 9:11
resonance with Styx (the ratios represent numbers
of orbits that are completed per unit time; the
period ratios are the inverses). Nix has been
measured to be 54 by 41 by 36 kilometres (33.6 mi
× 25.5 mi × 22.4 mi) in diameter, indicating a very
elongated shape, and a very high geometric albedo.
9.1 Charon - In 1978, astronomers discovered a
very large moon nearly half the size of Pluto.
This moon was called Charon.
Being so similar in size unlike most of the other planets
and their moons, Charon and Pluto formed a unique
system. Both Pluto and Charon orbit a common point in
space that lies in-between them, just like the orbits of
binary star systems, for this reason, Pluto and Charon
are referred as double planet, a double dwarf planet or a
binary system.
Charon and Pluto orbit each other every
6.387 days.
The mass and volume of Charon allow the calculation of
its density which is 1.702±0.021 g/cm from which it can
be determined the slightly less dense internals of Charon
than Pluto and thus Charon contains a larger proportion
of ice relative to rock in its interior.
Styx is a small natural satellite of
Pluto whose discovery was announced
on 11 July 2012.
Styx is very irregularly shaped, measuring 5 by 7
kilometres (3.1 mi × 4.3 mi). It is thought to have
formed from the debris lofted by a collision, which
could have led to losses of the more volatile ices,
such as those of nitrogen and methane, in the
composition of the impactors. The process is
expected to have created a body consisting mainly
of water ice.
Styx orbits the Pluto–Charon
at a
distance of 42,656 km, putting it between the orbits
of Charon and Nix.
Kerberos is a satellite of Pluto,
about 12 km in its longest dimension. It is the
fourth moon of Pluto that was discovered and
its existence was announced on 20 July 2011.
Kerberos has a double-lobed shape and is
approximately 11.9 km (7.4 mi) across in its long
dimension and 2.8 mi (4.5 km) in its shortest
dimension.
Observations indicate a circular, equatorial orbit
with the radius of approximately 58,000 km
(36,000 mi). Kerberos orbits between Nix
and Hydra and makes a complete orbit revolving
around Pluto roughly every 32.1 days.
Hydra is known as the outermost
known moon of Pluto. It was discovered along
with Nix in June 2005.
Hydra orbits around the barycentre of the system in
the same plane as Charon and Nix, at a distance of
about 65,000 km.
Hydra is irregularly shaped, 55 by 40 kilometres
(34.2 mi × 24.9 mi) in cross-section from one side.
It is specifically neutral like Charon and most
of Nix (whereas Pluto is reddish) and is composed
primarily of water ice, probably ice XI.

is often considered to be an empty, desolated place, the
region surrounding the Earth swarms with thousands
and millions of pieces, of debris created by our kind that
can lead to potential hazards for their artificially
functioning neighbours.
High Earth Orbit – A High Earth Obit (HEO)
is a geocentric orbit with an altitude entirely
above that of a geosynchronous orbit. The
orbital periods of such orbits are greater than
twenty four hours, therefore satellites in such a
orbit have an apparent retrograde motion.
In Low Earth Orbits, there are few "universal orbits"
which keeps the spacecraft in some particular rings.
LEO satellites can orbit in many planes, up to 15 times
in a day, causing frequent approaches between higher
density objects. Orbits of LEO are further changed
by the phenomena of perturbations which in case of
LEO include unevenness of the gravitational field of
Earth's, and these collisions can occur from any
direction. For such reasons, the Kessler syndrome can
be applied mostly towards the LEO region. Impacts can

and if dealt head on like the 2009 satellite

much spall in critical size range. These spall can cross
other orbits and can lead to a cascading effect. A
collision large enough like between a defunct satellite
and a space station could make low Earth
orbiting impossible.

In 2002, the Inter-Agency Debris
Coordination Committee published the "IADC Space
Debris Mitigation Guidelines," and presented these to
the UNCOPUOS Scientific & Technical Subcommittee
(STSC), where they served as a baseline for the "UN
Space Debris Mitigation Guidelines." In 2007 these
guidelines were approved by the 63 STSC member
nations as voluntary high-level mitigation measures.
Since the mid-1990s, space agencies in Europe have
developed more technically oriented guidelines as a
"European Code of Conduct," which was signed by
ASI, UKSA, CNES, DLR and ESA in 2006.
The core elements of this Code of Conduct are in line
with the IADC and UN guidelines. In order to tailor the
Code of Conduct to the needs of ESA projects, ESA has
developed its own "Requirements on Space Debris
Mitigation for Agency Projects". These instructions
came into force on 1 April 2008. They are applicable to
all future procurements of space systems (launchers,
satellites and inhabited objects).
A low Earth orbit (LEO) is
an orbit around Earth with an altitude between
160 km with an orbital period of about 88
minutes, and 2,000 kilometres with an orbital
period of about 127 minutes. Objects below
approximately 160 Km will experience very
rapid orbital decay and altitude loss. The
orbital velocity needed to maintain a stable low
Earth orbit is about 7.8 km/s, but reduces with
increased orbital altitude.

(MEO), sometimes called an intermediate

around the Earth above low earth orbit at an
altitude of 2000 Km and below geostationary
orbit of altitude 35,786 Km.
High Earth Orbit – A High Earth Obit (HEO)
is a geocentric orbit with an altitude entirely
above that of a geosynchronous orbit. The
orbital periods of such orbits are greater than
twenty four hours, therefore satellites in such a
orbit have an apparent retrograde motion.
Most of the space missions by private sector are
expected to be in low earth orbit. The satellites in LEO
are designed for military applications, scientific research
and a growing number for satellite communication
networks (e.g. IRIDUM, GLOBALSATAR, and
ORBCOM). In LEO, the satellite components and bus
are subjected to an increased level of radiation due to
energetic particles trapped by earth’s magnetic field and
encountering atmospheric drag from gases by increasing
the thermospheric density levels of the upper
atmosphere. Space environment can also create
electrification, ionizing damage, surface deterioration
and collision. Nearly 40% of satellites malfunction were
induced by space environment.

Numerous evolutionists have long hoped to find evidence of life in space. They reason that if life evolved on Earth,
then it could have evolved elsewhere. If, as the argument goes, there are endless planets throughout the universe that
have formed via natural procedures, there must be other Earth-like planets. Many think that finding such a planet
outside our solar system would be relatively similar to finding evidence of life in space. Humans need to answer two
main questions regarding exoplanets. 1) Do they exist? and 2) How did they form? The second question has to do
with starting point science, but the first has to do with experimental evidence. Scripture does not tell us whether other
stars have planets, so we must apply the best observational science we can to answer the question. Scientists have
searched for years for planets orbiting other stars. These are called extrasolar planets, or ‘exoplanets’. Astronomers
first obtained evidence suggesting extrasolar planets around 1995 while studying the sunsized star 51-Pegasi. Today
there are research teams around the world searching for extrasolar planets with greatly refined research techniques.
There are now over 450 objects catalogued in exoplanet lists. But all these experiments are done in the plane of our
solar system where aberrations are experienced due to the celestial bodies inside our solar system including the large
Kuiper belt. Even the Hubble Space Telescope is situated in the plane of our planetary system. Also, exoplanet
imaging techniques such as radial velocity method, transit photometry and direct imaging is less efficient while
observing the line of sights horizontal and parallel to our solar system disc. The planes of solar systems in the
universe are all oriented in different directions. What determines their orientations is the direction of the angular
momentum that the system had when it formed, and that’s pretty much random. Our own solar system is inclined by
about 63 degrees with respect to the plane of the milky way galaxy. Experimenting for extra solar planets from
outside the plane of our solar system will provide best results and allow images to be taken even in the directions not
explored before. This paper will focus on the merits and de-merits of performing Exoplanet experiments and imaging
outside the plane of our solar system. Also, this paper will discuss possible locations and exit paths for our solar
system for future space missions.

Every year, humans send information gathering missions into space. As the missions turn out to be progressively
modern, the measure of information they can assemble and need to send to Earth is rapidly rising. Exchanging radio
signals between spacecraft in deep space is easier compared with getting those signals back to Earth, especially when
the spacecraft is 120 billion miles away. Despite the fact that we’ve sent spacecrafts billions of miles into space and
rovers are gathering illuminating data about the planets, moons, and even asteroids, radio communication in space
still remains the new wilderness. While the missions themselves are a marvel of technical wizardry, so too is the
Herculean feat of not simply conveying between spacecrafts but rather sending signals back to Earth. Man’s greatest
achievement in this regard is the Voyager spacecraft, that 38 years later is still communicating with Earth from more
than 120 billion miles away, and has outlived even the most optimistic projections of longevity. NASA recently
celebrated the 25th anniversary of the last time Voyager sent its last images to Earth. Soon, it will be time when the
Voyagers and other interstellar probes will send their last signal and will be lost in the intergalactic space. The deep
space data collected and sent back to Earth by the interstellar probes is extremely essential to mankind and possesses
the ability to answer questions that humans have been asking since decades. As more scientific questions arise, the
ability to answer them requires more sophisticated instruments that generate even more data which requires a
productive space communication arrangement which can be utilized by mankind for the upcoming years. Earth has
its own telecommunication network, analogous to which, this paper will provide an all-inclusive strategy to set up a
communication network in space to survey our planetary system constantly, provide a more effective network for our
existing and future space missions and increase the efficiency of deep space communication. This paper will provide
a strategy for a telecommunication probe network and reasonable locations of the probes in and around our solar
system which will assist humankind in breaking down and observing the solar system constantly and send signals
back to earth more effectively. Also, this paper will throw light on how this strategy can support future space
missions and increase the time for which our probes such as Voyager I II will return signals back to earth.
The NASA Deep Space Network is a worldwide
network of U.S. spacecraft communication facilities that
helps to explore the farthest points of our solar system
by performing radio and Radar astronomy operations. It
has three ground stations located approximately 120
degrees apart on Earth in the United States (California),
Spain (Madrid), and Australia (Canberra) which ensures
that any satellite in the deep space is able to
communicate with atleast one station at all times. The
ground stations also communicate with satellites in
order to initiate course corrections, provide software
